comments:
This didatic course examines the diagnostic and management issues related to the care of acutely ill adults. Students examine the pathophysiologic as well as the psychosocial influences underlying acute illness and injury. The dynamic interplay of assessment, diagnosis, management and treatment options relevant to patients with acute illnesses and injuries is examined in detail. An evidence-based approach to the nursing and medical management as well as pharmacologic and other therapies is emphasized. Content will focus on patients with cardiovascular, pulmonary, infectious and nutritional issues. Course involves one test, one paper, and the review of numerous case studies.

This class involved lectures with numerous guest speakers and multiple case studies. Students generally felt that they gained a lot of knowledge from the class. Comments included that the class “pushed students to look at things in a new manner and challenge themselves.” Several reported that a good amount of reading was involved, which covered numerous “interesting” topics. Many students felt that the case studies were great in adding depth to the information. Grading was considered a bit difficult, as only one test played into the semester’s grade.

This course had numerous professors and students generally felt that all were extremely knowledgeable on the topic, conveying the information in a manner that allowed everyone to understand. The professors of this course were all described as “supportive and amazing.” Often times, students wished that Professor Pawlow taught the entire course instead of having guest speakers because they felt that Professor Pawlow presented knowledge in a better manner. Other students added that she made herself available for meetings.

Most students took the class because it was mandatory for the nursing degree. Many reported that having only one exam was difficult as far as grades were concerned. Regardless of difficulty, students generally felt that the class helped them think about how to use what was learned in class “clinically.” While the course was “time consuming,” several students reported that it bettered their understanding of clinical research. The case studies were “excellent at testing the knowledge learned.”

Nursing 761 is a didactic course that examines the diagnostic and management issues related to the care of acutely ill adults. Students will examine the pathophysiologic, as well as the psychosocial, influences underlying acute illness and injury. The dynamic interplay of assessment, diagnosis, management and treatment options relevant to patients with acute illnesses and injuries is examined in detail. An evidence-based approach to the nursing and medical management as well as pharmacologic and other therapies is emphasized. The course content focuses on patients with cardiovascular, pulmonary, infectious and nutritional issues. . 

This class included lectures with numerous guest speakers and studied multiple case studies. Students generally felt that they gained a lot of knowledge from the class. Comments included that the class “pushed students to look at things in a new manner and challenge themselves.” A good amount of reading was involved, which covered numerous “interesting” topics, according to one student. Many students felt that the case studies were great in adding depth to the information. 

This course had numerous professors, and students generally commented that all were extremely knowledgeable on the topic and conveyed the information in a manner that allowed everyone to understand. The professors of this course were all described as “supporting and amazing.” Most students wished that Professor Pawlow taught the entire course instead of having guest speakers because Professor Pawlow could convey the knowledge in a better manner. Many noted that she made herself available for meetings. 

Most students reported taking the class because it was mandatory for a nursing degree. Many felt that having only one exam was difficult as far as grades. Regardless of difficulty, students seemed to feel that the class helped them to think about how to use what was learned in class “clinically.” While the course was “time consuming,” it bettered students’ understanding of clinical research. The case studies were “excellent at testing the knowledge learned.” This course included one test, one paper, and the review of numerous case studies.
